CLIST.TITLE: Patents
CLIST.ITEM:
United States Patent and Trademark Officehttps://www.uspto.gov/
enHTML (searchhttp://patft.uspto.gov/
enHTML)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Probably the most well-known computer article: Turing is defining his imitation test.
This very long article speaks about a fibre-optic cable linking England to Japan and a lot of other things. This is simply one of the best articles I ever read.
Tim presents what is and what is not LDAP, he summarizes its history and gives examples of its current use.

This could have been the usual Wired vision (a kind of technological/financial optimism) but Dickey is not usually writing for the magazine, so the description of French start-up's is less enthusiastic than expected.

X.T: Welcome to Sealand. Now Bugger Off.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: When cyberpunk SF becomes true: some cypherpunks try to create an offshore/offjurisdiction data haven on a WWII antiaircraft platform.
What happens to the code when a company dies… Most of the times, it is lost, but not always: the example of Dragon's NaturallySpeaking.
A presentation of MisterHouse, a software to automate home devices. Take care to bugs in your scripts…
Using metaphor with other human activities can be useful to formulate questions, but is dangerous when used to justify answers.

X.T: Is your laptop a pain in the neck?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Muscular-skeletal disorders are more frequent with laptops.
The idea to interrogate some well-known programmers if programming as an art is good, but the result is slightly disappointing.
The author describes the problems with community documentation and a possible rating system. I don't feel this one is realistic…
The problem of word losing their real meaning when they are in fashion.

X.T: Using Google to View MySpace or Any Restricted Site

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some well-known tricks to bypass simple Web filters.

X.ST: Community topics pave the way for a new twist on developer collaboration

ARTICLE.COMMENT: IBM is updating its developer site to Web 2.0.

X.T: Microsoft unveils touch screen computing - Giant computer blends reality with virtual reality

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A demo of Microsoft tabletop touch computer.
Geogers Dyson tells a history of Von Neumann's computer work full of anecdotes.

X.T: Beyond mobile broadband, WiMAX is about blowing up the wireless business model

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Why WiMax is more than just a new wireless standard.

X.T: The Three Projections of Doctor Futamura

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: ShapeWriter: making gesture writing on mobile devices easy, fast, and fun

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of ShapeWriter, a software to recognize words of a soft keyboard, with some impressive demos.
The title says all.

X.T: Lone Star Ruby Conference 2010 Real Software Engineering by Glenn Vanderburg

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Software engineering is different of the other engineering domains, software engineering must be defined by the practitioners, source code is a model…

X.ST: The Computer History Simulation Project and SIMH

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of SIMH, a multi-system emulator.

X.T: Where Did This Code Come From? Discovering the Provenance of Program Binaries

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using statistical machine learning to infer the language, compiler, author… of some binary code.

X.T: Meet the tireless entrepreneur who squatted at AOL

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Eating, sleeping, practicing sport, showering in AOL building while trying to launch a startup.

X.T: Shyam Sankar: The rise of human-computer cooperation
Shyam Sankar: The rise of human-computer cooperation

ARTICLE.COMMENT: While I agree with the idea that intelligently using a simple software is more productive that trying to implement and blindly use a more complex algorithm, this presentation smells as bullshit with many samples seeming a biased description of simple computer usage.

X.T: Robert C. Martin - Professional Software Development

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Short iterations, never be blocked (because waiting for someone else), screaming architectures (architectures should express the domain, not the technologies they use), incremental improvements (instead of the big rewrite), TDD, saying "no".

X.T: Txt2tags: A great lightweight markup language for many tasks

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very short presentation of Txt2tags.

X.T: ‘Leap Second’ Bug Wreaks Havoc Across Web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Amazon, LinkedIn, Foursquare… failed to manage the leap second, Google was prepared and had no problem.

X.T: Erik Meijer: Latency, Native Relativity and Energy-Efficient Programming

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some thoughts about extending the usual time vs space duality by considering latency and energy.
The advantages and the problems with programs that support being customized from the inside.
The end of Unix 32 bits epoch.
Picking a language, Scala, in order to attract developers to work in your company.
Some advice for solving a problem: read the error message, google the error message, ask a peer, ask an expert, record the resolution.

X.T: Tim Ewald - Clojure: Programming with Hand Tools

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The tools you use change the way you see the world, see Maslow's hammer.

X.ST: Adventures in Unicode, Real-time Streaming, and Media Culture

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A long decription of how Emojitracker has been built.
Perfect agile teams are very rare. The open source model, with a small core of "foremen" reviewing patches of all the contributors, is seen much more often and proved to be effective.
Some high level ideas about morphogenesis: TBD automates, Turing machines, cellular automata, L-systems… But there is no details about implementing a morphogenesis algorithm.
Forcing oneself to write code every day.

X.T: Yes, you can speak at a conference

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author advices to give talks at conferences, this is a good way to learn, and he gives some counsel to prepare these talks.
Building tools to get more frequent and more comprehensive feedback.
Some stories of the past time in TekLabs and some comments about today.

X.T: Why Good Developers Write Bad Code: An Observational Case Study of the Impacts of Organizational Factors on Software Quality

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A study of the problems met by a development team: there is nothing surprising here, but the description of these problems is clear.
Uncle Bob explains his hypothesis why men have replaced women in computing: this occurred when people realized that programming means power.
The history of Apple I.

X.T: It's All Good: The False Dichotomy Between Planned and Improvisational Projects

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Planned projects and agile ones are not contradictory, both are better than the other ones in some situations.
Kent's process for promoting an idea.

X.T: In The Beginning: The Birth Story in Idea to Impact

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A complement of the previous blog: the totem of an idea can be the story of its birth.
The vicious circle of using kludges to limit code change and risk, and having these kludges making the code even riskier to change.

X.T: How to Build a High Velocity Development Team

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some common ideas expressed with strong words and little facts.
Bullshit around XP's sustainable pace of 40 hours per week.

X.T: GOTO 2015 • Developing Like There's No Tomorrow • Frank Lyaruu

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of Sendrato's wristband used for tracking participants to an event.
The first part describes some old mechanism to generate pieces of art. The second part is a fuzzy description of implementing analogy mechanisms.
A good analysis of the advantages/disadvantages of co-located vs remote teams.

X.T: John Carmack’s Deep Thoughts: Ideas, Work, and Emotion

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some interesting thought about ideas.
A good description of the problem with V8's Math.random() implementation
The title says all.

X.T: Lean Startup: la méthode qui plante 93 start-up sur 100

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some basic advice dismantling some fads popular among startups.

X.T: Docker: A boon for the modern developer
X.ST: Make the transition to containerized apps to increase coding productivity and boost your development IQ

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overenthusiastic introduction to Docker.

X.T: Code Golf & the Bitshift Variations - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Explaining a C code-golf generating music.

X.T: Facebook Hired Me At 18. But My Story Isn’t As Perfect As It Sounds.
X.ST: I have the opportunity to share the imperfect story. To share what it's like to succeed in a world where everything is falling down around you.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Michael Sayman, the "successful kid who built apps and inspires others", explains that his life was much less happy than it seemed.

X.T: Shorter Feedback is not Always Bett

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Having a shorter feedback loop does not help if the Controller / System / Sensor system is not stable…
Experimenting with a training format mixing short videos and chat.

X.ST: How the image of software developers came about

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How the situation changd from the initial women working on the ENIAC to the current software world which is strongly dominated by males.

X.T: How Big Data Creates False Confidence

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Numbers extracted from big data should be interpreted with care instead of being blindly trusted.
Real time dashboards are a source of disturbance and are not helpful to solve the real problems.
Kent starts explaining his model of product development: Explore / Expand / Extract.

X.T: A Good Craftsman Never Blames His Tools

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to handle the fact that you join, as a consultant, a team that is using tools that you would like to change.

X.T: Carina Zona - Consequences of an Insightful Algorithm

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A long list of bad side effects of data mining and some advice on being responsible when using deep learning.
Reed-Muller code and building it using Hadamard matrices.

X.T: Reed-Muller Code (64 Shades of Grey pt2) - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The continuation of the previous video.

X.T: Developers Who Use Spaces Make More Money Than Those Who Use Tabs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: StackOverfow data shows that salary is positively correlated to using spaces for indentation.
A high level description of OCR algorithms.

X.T: 5 Step Recipe: Everything You Need to Know for Staying Up-to-Date in Java

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Lessons from my first year of live coding on Twitch

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Why Computers are Bad at Algebra | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A basic and clear explanation of IEEE 754.

X.T: 10 Tips on How to be a Great Programmer

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: VW engineer sent to the clink for three years for emissions-busting code
X.ST: James Liang gets 40 months on the cooler and $200,000 fine

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A first minor executive is sentenced.
Trying to draw a 2D map of the different domains of computer science.

X.ST: A small group of programmers wants to change how we code—before catastrophe strikes.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A non technical presentation of some ideas to change the way software is built: Bret Victor's Light Table, Eric Bantégnie's Esterel, Leslie Lamport's TLA+.
A comment on the previous article: the solution is not more tools, but better programming discipline.
About the few who codemn political incorrectness by using dishonorable means.
A rational against hiring quotas.

X.T: The Biggest Software Mistake That Small Business Owners Make

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This article states the obvious: having a single developer is a bad situation.
The end of Moore's Law means that the software industry will have reach adulthood and get more professional.
The history of data storage and its impact on software design.
An analogy with flying a plane, but the message is always the same: trying to go fast without taking care of the quality will slow you down.

X.T: Master Data Management définition : gestion des données de référence

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short overview of what is Master Data Management.
The problem of being able to read files or execute programs several years after their creation.
KentBeck uses an analogy with poker to explain that, in large companies where projects take more time, developers work on less projects and chose the ones with less risk.
DDD is an offensive term because it is a bra size.
8th Light staff is listing the technologies which are gaining popularity.
A presentation of Martin Gardner's Hexapawn.

X.T: Yes, You Can Write an Awesome Game in Just 10 Lines of Basic
X.ST: An annual contest challenges programmers to create 8-bit games of intrigue and adventure

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A competition of games written with 10 lines of Basic.

X.T: New Approach Could Sink Floating Point Computation

ARTICLE.COMMENT: John Gustafson is proposing a new floating point format: Posits.
An explanation of the undecidability of the halting problem using Python.
A description of the EPUB format.
A high level introduction to gradual typing, a language feature allowing parts of a program to be dynamically typed and other parts to be statically typed.
A history of the type systems in computer languages.
A good overview of the current implementation of multithreading at the CPU level: CMP, CMT, FMT, SMT…

X.T: Near-Optimal Parallel Join Processing in MapReduce

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
A very technical presentation of an algorithm to implement join models in a MapReduce framework (see also this paperhttps://www.ccs.neu.edu/home/mirek/papers/2011-SIGMOD-ParallelJoins.pdf
enPDF).

The authors explain that sequential consistency should be maintained instead of the current memory model of C, C++ and Java. This would simplify developers life while the performance loss would be acceptable.

X.T: Four Solutions to a Trivial Problem - Guy Steele Jr.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to parallelize the resolution of the volume of water held in a histogram, and some manifesto on the fact we must change our coding paradigms to be able to use parallelisation.

Some unusual ideas to make you think: kill agile, Scrum is talking about code instead of coding, a company should have a closed feedback loop to react to its environment, push in production instead of doing TDD…
Commenting the previous video.

X.T: The Responsive Enterprise: Embracing the Hacker Way
X.ST: Soon every company will be a software company.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Software is omnipresent, companies must work in closed-loop mode, effective organisations are hierarchical, developers must be well paid and handle the tactics while senior leaders handle the strategy…

X.T: LZW Patent and Software Information - License Information on GIF and Other LZW-based Technologies

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The real legal status of the LZW patent: it will be expired July 7, 2004 in the last country (Canada).
This is the report of a phone call between Tim and Jeff: they have spoken about the patent issue.
